comment: I guess it tastes good; it's very sweet. It doesn't remind me of a rye whiskey at all; it just reminds me of Crown Royal.

Hats off for the recent win and being a decent sipper at a pocket friendly price. All that being said not my go-to. In my personal opinion a little too simple for all the hype but then again I have four bottles on my shelf...damn the masses!
Good rye, smooth and a reasonable price... Not a world beater though.
Interesting to watch the jump in reviews of this after Murray's selection.

Three stars, but a glowing three stars--a better whisky than three stars would indicate. Very fruity (lots of apple), rye spice, clove, baking spice, warm rye bread. Light in flavour (lighter than 45% ABV would suggest). Lots of caramels and vanillas. Recognizably Crown Royal in profile (a bit of a dusty, almost sawdust-y character, and a bourbon-lite sort of character), but something nice and something different. Closest parallel flavour-wise might be a mix of Sazerac and a high-rye Canadian whisky. For the price, it's real nice.
Fantastic notes, taste, if and only if, mix with a drop of water or ice cube.

For the price this is a real great rye whisky, it reminds me of George Dickel rye , sweet with a nice balance of spice , soft on the palate  , no alcohol burn despite 45% alc. It's not a world whisky of the year but a bang for your buck award , a good Canadian rye. Buy it !
I actually like this as a sipping rye. I've had better & worse but at this price point a winner

On the nose its deluxe turned up to eleven. Lots of sweet rye and some fruity notes. The palate finds subtle spice and more stone fruit. The finish is quick and refreshing just like its cousin the deluxe. While its a lighter departure compared to American ryes, its very tasty and quite enjoyable!

This is honestly a disappointing whisky. I cannot believe it was claimed to be the best whisky in the world by the whisky bible. Nose is overly sweet, typical rye. Palate follows the nose. Finish is alcohol forward and zero depth in complexity. Save your money and don't waste your time.
I'm not a big rye person, so I may be biased. I work in a liquor store, and we did a tasting. No one was impressed, although we all agreed it was a decent rye.

I tried this the day JIM Murray named it the 2015 Whiskey of the Year.

I think Mr Murray was paid off.  As I sipped this neat.  All I could think of was... This is innocuous.

Barreled review from December 2016. 


Another review from the brother in laws Canadian home bar. 

This whisky is 90% rye, not sure what the other 10% is but I would guess either corn or wheat. This one is 45% ABV, a copper amber color that I'm sure has colorant in it and probably chill filtered. 

Rye bread a plenty on the nose and again I get some baked fish. It's an odd sort of sensation to get fish on the nose of a whisky. There is some vanilla and cinnamon as well. Nicer than the Canadian Club I had just before this, but not remarkably so. Very light fruitiness in the background. 

Remarkably smooth palate that is spicy at the same time. Rye bread, and a bit floral. A hint of vanilla in there as well. There is something that gives a cooling sensation reminiscent of mint or menthol without the taste of either. Hard to describe further than that. 

Granted my knowledge of ryes is limited, with almost no American ryes under my belt, but I could see myself buying a bottle of this if I felt like a rye. I know it's a blend and therefore engineered to be smooth and easy to drink, but it's good. I don't believe it's whisky of the year good, but good nonetheless. 3.5
Very good next to a few other Canadian Whiskies. Still doesn't hold a match to a good bourbon.
Apparently voted the best whisky in the world for 2015 by whisky bible.

Too bitter of an aftertaste for me.  I have had plenty of rye whiskey in my day and I can attest to the fact that this is not a typical rye.  I bought a bottle of whisky on the recommendation that is the whiskey of the year 2015 according to the Whiskey Bible.  I will never drink this again.
It's okay but certainly not the best in the world or even near the top.
Not sure why it garnered best whisky this year. Overly sweet with not much to recommend it in terms of taste. Admittedly my palatte leans more to Islay's so take my review with a pinch of salt.

This was on my "to try" list before it was named whiskey of the year, but Mr. Murray bumped it to the top of my list. Picked up a 375ml on my last ABC excursion. This pours in the glass with a light golden straw color. Nose is pleasantly sweet, but alcohol heavy, with a definite rye note. Neat it enters thin and hot with none of the sweet transferring from the nose. Rye bread with a dill pickle note. Dry & Bitter, citrus peel, astringent finish that coats and unpleasantly lingers. It reminds me of my first (and last) taste of a small microbrewery IPA. A splash or a cube or two of ice does bring a touch of sweetness to the mix and reduces, but does not eliminate, the bitter citrus finish. Tried it in an Old Fashioned thinking maybe it would shine as a mixer but the bitter finish is still an issue. I definitely don't feel this is Whiskey of the year material. Glad I only bought the 375ml.
Much better for less than $30/750ml than it has any right to be.  Notes of everything they say it has, to the tune of green apple Jolly Rancher.
This is a great whisky. Best I have ever had from crown royal. The rye is not so aggressive, but fruity and floral. One of my favourite ryes. For the price I would for sure buy again
Very nice drinkable rye. Not as spicy as my favorite Rittenhouse but has a better buttery follow through. But as ryes go, there are better and cheaper.

Nose - Smells like apple brown betty in a glass. Toasted oats, faint hint of chocolate, caramel, cinnamon, nutmeg. Slightly sun melted apple jolly rancher.
Taste - Yup, tastes kind of like apple brown betty too. Sweet baked apples with brown sugar with a hint of cinnamon. You get almost no wood influence taste here. Starts off sweet and fades to something slightly bitter, like if you accidently bit into an apple seed. There's also a very very faint hint of dill in there as well just near the end.
Finish - The fruity apple slowly fades to the apple seed bitterness that's sort of like a grapefruit pith, but not as citrusy. Slight progressive warmth from the front of the tongue to the back, not really an alcohol burn, but a gentle warmth which is nice.
81/100

[NOSE] Instant appreciation of pleasant oaks. Followed by cinnamon, apple juice, brown sugar, honey. Bold alcohol hints in the background. [PALATE] Sweet arrival: brown sugar, some toffee.  Cinnamon, clove, fruity bubble gum. Light hint of bourbon gluey tone. Some burns down the throat. [FINISH] Peppermint, bitter orange, gentle spice. Short lasting. [COMMENT] This is not a typical rye whisky; relatively smooth & easy to drink.  But took me some tries to appreciate individual flavors. Great nose, ok taste, but finish is quite plain. Best whisky of the year…? Probably not.. (88/100)
Fruit on the nose, with flavour of currant and some plum notes. Sweet with boozy warmth.

I am a bourbon guy and don't care a whole bunch for most ryes. That being said, I find this to be an excellent whiskey. I'm not sure that I would rate this the best in the world this year, but it is an excellent offering from the folks at Crown Royal.  On the nose, you definitely pick up the rye notes. I also get a sweet fruit smell. Someone described it as juicy fruit gum. I think that is spot on. On the palate, this one is fairly light. The rye burn hits immediately followed by a light oak. Not overly complicated. Tastes pretty young if you ask me. Is this good. Yeah. Is it a great value for $35. Yeah. Whiskey of the year. Meh....
Smooth, hints of honey. Can definitely tell it's a rye

Okay, so after Jim Murray's declaration of this as the "best whisky in the world", I finally bought a bottle.  More so out of curiousity than anything else; normally I'd not even consider Crown Royal ( my apologies...not as a snob, but if I'm going to have my liver take a hit, I want it worthwhile).  I'm not sure if Murray actually meant this as the "best" in the world, or simply "most unappreciated".  The nose is floral and fragrant, palette is very un-rye like.   By that I mean that I can't detect the usual suspects like mint and eucalyptus cough syrup.  Instead I taste more spices, like nutmeg.  And candied banana.  Sort of like those sweet banana chips you find south of the border (like Mexico...not N.Carolina).  Finish is smooth.  I didn't expect this smoothness.  I expected a fiery, bitter finish indicative of youth or poor quality.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Crown Royal can be drunk as is, without mixing into soda?!!?   My very humble verdict...If in the next life, I am born as a world famous whiskey writer (among other things like famous bollywood movie star, husband of a Brazilian supermodel, and avid collector of Lamboriginis), I'm not sure I'd have this as my "best whisky in the world" choice.  I'd not even have this as my favorite rye (that for me is High West MidWinter).   But I'd surely have this as "most under-appreciated" choice.  And I'm sure my gorgeous Brazilian supermodel will fully concur, as will my billions of Bollywood fans.
Amazing flavor at an even more amazing price.  If you have $30 to spend and want the most bang for your buck, this is it.

For a rye from a basic bitch distillery, this lived up to the hype. Surprisingly smooth, and a delightful butterscotch aftertaste that paired wonderfully with a Cohiba Siglos II. At $34 a pop (in Quebec. Shut up.) I don't feel bad putting this in my flask. Four stars because it's Crown Royal that doesn't need a mixer.

Vanilla, apricot and spearmint notes on the nose. On the pallet you get the spicInes of the rye with a firm alcohol burn. Not the most refined whiskey,  but there is so much going on here. Great buy for the price point.

Yes, interesting. I usually avoid crown royal because it is so cloyingly sweet... but I guess I'll have to try this one now. I would take Jim Murrays review with a grain of salt however, he gives 97pts to Canada's Hiram Walker rye too which is swill and needs a healthy dose of gingersale to drink. Perhaps Canadian whiskey is becoming exotic to the world markets and a novelty on return?

Decent whiskey. Not quite enough interest in the nose or the palate to have me coming back, but it was worth visiting. This is one of the rare times where I think the Distiller tasting notes are spot on. Unfortunately, this whiskey suffers from a bit from being too uniform, and too easy to understand. It's tasty, but there is no depth to the nose or the palate. To he honest, I can't really recommend this whiskey. It is ok, and you won't go wrong in getting in, but you could get much better for less. I can't even recommend it as a whiskey to keep for your non-whiskey drinking friends. I'd say something like Dickel no. 12 is better for that.
I don't know what makes a whiskey the best in the world, but this is by far the best rye in my collection and my fav for a Manhattan. Good on its own too!

Fruity and creamy before the rye spice takes over. Like a combination of Gibson's Finest, Appleton Estate, and Bushmills. It's really does smell and taste exactly like Juicy Fruit :) Unfortunately that doesn't make for a good whisky. $35 in Ontario.
Okay tasting (tastes like standard Crown Royal), mixes well with Ginger Ale (standard Rye and Ginger).

If the original Crown Royale is a perfect starter whisky (it is) then this is a perfect "leveling up" whisky for when you're ready to try something a little more robust. Like its grandaddy, Northern Harvest is quite smooth, but with some attitude and swagger.
Fruit and mint on the nose, pear comes through as it opens up.  Spice and banana on the tongue, with a touch of burn.  Smooth finish that lingers on the tongue.
Fruity and sweet indeed. Very smooth and quite light, with a hint of spice to keep it balanced

4/2016. Must've forgotten to note when I had this over at Ryan's. This is an excellent whiskey. Crisp, fruity and low and growing spice in the background. Best crown I've had. Makes it harder and harder to return to the PBR Rodeo level stuff.
Lovely smooth, sweet rye. Lower on spice than some ryes. Easy neat drinking.

Say what you will about Jim Murray but I think the whisky world needs people to shake up the traditional orthodoxy and to generate conversation and controversy.  Crown Royal Rye is a noticeable step up from the standard Crown Royal (2 stars in my estimation).  Some nice spiciness on the nose, a vanilla sweetness and palate and mellow peppery finish.  There's none of the overbearing, cloying manufactured taste of the standard bottling.  Of course this is overrated, but it's an affordable Canadian rye that's easy to drink neat.  Recommended.
Pretty complex, each taste is a little different. Not much nose, but nice palate with vanilla, oak, spice and some fruit, among others. Peppery finish. Not a bad rye, but I prefer others.
Overall it's not what I expected from this bottle.  It's a fine Whiskey to use as a mix.  Price point is right for this particular brand.  Personally will not repeat once gone.  Maybe a gift bottle.
A good drink. Not as complex and the finish is smooth. Goes down quickly. $44

The nose is reminiscent of walking into the kitchen when someone is baking pies; I get apple with raisin and mincemeat, with a handful of fall spices...very unique, especially from a standard bearer such as CR.  The palate is another surprise, opening soft and fruity, almost like an unpeated Highland, before moving into a very mellow mint that takes you to a slightly woody, astringent finish with just enough alcohol burn to ensure it's not overly sweet.  This is good whisky, and well worth seeking out.

I am Canadian. I am very happy that Jim Murray put Canadian whisky on the map (again). Do I think this is a whisky of the year candidate. No, not really. Is this a good whisky? Yup, it is. It can be used as a sipper or mixed into a cocktail very easily. Here in Ontario it costs $34. I'd take a $34 whisky that tastes like this as an everyday dram any day (love the 45 ABV too). Though I have to admit, for $5 more, I'd still go with the Lot  40 (one of the great Canadian whisky's that's been ignored until recently).

Jim Murray's whisky of year 2015
PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES:
Nose: Baking spices, cereal, light wood spices
Palate: Gentle oak note, rich butterscotch, spiced vanilla, develops into soft peppery notes
Finish: Smooth and creamy
Cinnamon cedar nose. Caramel notes on the palate turn to an array of herbs and spices: Mint, rosemary,  and a pepper finish. Refreshing.
Nice..maybe to mellow and sweet.. not sure if i get that rye spice that i wanted.over all not bad..

Nose- overly sweet on the initial nosing, fruity, brown sugar syrup, 
Tasting- very sweet on the first sip, almost unpleasant sweet.

It has taken me three different occasions to finally PARTIALLY appreciate this whiskey. The hints of pear and caramel are wonderful, but the burn is terrible. Though not unpardonable, this whisky is largely forgettable.
Definite fruity notes. Apple, nutmeg, banana, cinnamon
Spice and vanilla on the nose. With a dab of water. Stays hot, spivey, smooth. Dry finish. A late medicinal smell to me.

It is an interesting whiskey, the nose definitely stands out but it did not hold up on the palate. It kind of fell flat for me there, some of those spicey notes came through that were held up by some of the sweeter candy notes and the finish had some serious hot spice which I did like.
Good for the price. On the sweeter side of ryes, but not in a bad way; very unique. I get apples, brown sugar, and cinnamon on the nose. Grapes (?), apple, up front with a long spicy, peppery finish.
Not at all what I expected and a bit disappointed. This is not what I would call exceptionally smooth as described by Crown Royal.  The alcohol burn is excessive. Not a repeat purchase in my future.

I like rye quite a bit. This whisky is great. It is extremely distinct and recognizable. It is smooth and carries with it undertones of simple fruits and spices. The sweetness is approaching that of a bourbon. This drink earned its top spot. This is a whisky to share with good friends. $36.99 a bottle as of today.
For a Crown Royal product this is excellent. For a rye... Uh... Hmm. Yeah...
Bitter mint toothpaste that burns, despite the addition of water.  CR has really let me down big time.  Looks like no more velvet bags for me.
It's a good sweet drinker with some spice, but seriously Jim, I've had better

I'm not much of a rye drinker due to the spicy taste and this has that. After letting it sit for a few minutes it really cuts the strong cinnamon taste. Not as smooth as I have come to expect from Crown

Definitely the best Crown Royal I've had. Is it a Whisky of the Year? I don't think so. Personally, I believe Bulleit makes a better rye. Jim Murray has them separated by two points, but I give the edge to Bulleit. Worth the price and worth having in the cabinet.

Drinking neat: The description on Distiller is pretty accurate. Like walking through an irrigated orchard on a summer day. Sweet fruits, leaves, branches, earth, with a hint of spearmint. For such a high rye bill I'm surprised how much the grain takes control giving big caramel butter popcorn note. Oak is apparent throughout giving somewhat of a cider like aroma with vanilla ever present. There's some nice spice to it but for the most part sweet fruits and earth are in control making this whiskey closer to a scotch rather than what you would expect from an American rye. A pleasant and easy drinking dram. I usually don't drink the same thing over and over but I can easily make an exception for this one.

This is actually not too bad. I expected worse, from a lower-shelf crown offering, but was pleasantly surprised. At its heart, it's rich and spicy, though the flavors are hard to distinguish- I imagine it's due to the blend's age and price point. But, the nose is sweet and reminds me of baked apples and cinnamon, there's brown sugar, oak and rye on the palate, and a strange finish that morphs from the spicy rye to a more fruity, plum-ey taste with a sweet mintiness that lingers for quite a while. Was more of a 3 when I opened it but enjoyed it more as I drank it.

In celebration of Canada’s 150th birthday, I decided to open up a bottle of Jim Murray’s “whisky of the year 2016.”  I picked this one up on sale for $28.  As a Canadian who grew up in Toronto, I know how bad Canadian whiskey is, and of course I’m intrigued by a Canadian product that has made such a large splash.  While Jim Murray is probably the world’s best known whisk(e)y critic, he drinks over 1,000 whiskies per year.  That makes him an alcoholic – and alcoholics are not to be trusted.  NOSE: Big oakiness and spice.  The typical inoffensive vanilla and toffee characteristic of Crown Royal is hiding like Bruce Banner here.  The rye strikes a sharp second note.  Quickly, this gives the impression that this not the pacifist Canada; this is Canada circa WWI; this is FLQ circa 1970 Canada.  PALATE: So odd, a Crown Royal with bite.  Typical apples and pears fruitiness quickly gets taken over by oak and spiciness from cinnamon, spearmint, and cayenne.  There is a familiar vanilla sweetness definitely present, but dominated by the spiciness and bitterness of a 90% rye mash bill.  The mouthfeel is moderate, initially tasting like a low ABV whiskey, but as you swallow, this burns like it was 50+ ABV.  FINISH: There is a finish!  That’s a big accomplishment for crown.  The burn gives way to apples, pears, and toffee.  There is a grassy freshness and something a little funky.  Dare I say, cannabis oil?  The aftertaste lasts 3-5 minutes.  VERDICT: Not the best bottle of whiskey I bought in 2016 (that goes to Laphroaig 10 Cask Strength).  Not the best Canadian whiskey I tried in 2016 (that goes to Glen Breton 17 Ice wine cask finish).  Not the best rye whiskey I tried in 2016 (that goes to Whisky Pig The Boss Hog Edition 3).  But this is the best bottle of Crown Royal in the world.  Cheers Jim Murray Eh!  Happy Canada Day.  82/100
I really like this rye. It used to be my "everyday" whiskey. Absolutely deliciously well-priced.
Way better than I expected. Easy drinking - almost light rye.
Vanilla, butterscotch, fresh oak and overripe melons on the nose. Dried fruit, bananas, cloves and cinnamon on the palate. The finish is sweet, slightly mentholated and of medium length. Not bad.
Pretty good. I was surprised at the nice rye flavor this has.

13/20
riche, doux, des pointes de miel
sans caractère particulier. se boit bien
wonderful rye, so easy to drink you need.to watch yourself. Initially sweet, then mild spicy finish. almost as good as Sazerac rye at half the price and easy to find. often on sale for less than $25

I hadn't drunk a 90% rye until this came in on a bargin and last year's world whiskey award recommendations.  I can see the notes are talking it down, but let us take it from where it is.  Raisins.  Raisins and a good spiciness.  It's good.  The aroma is nice and fruity, but the tongue feel is thin and the after taste is as well.  It finishes short.  The rye seems to give a good antidote to the sweetness of other north american corn based distillates.  It's a full 90% rye in the mash bill, which makes it an unusual offering.  I don't know what the remaining 10% is.  Overall, I like it's approach and can see myself drinking more rye.  But it needs to pick up the end of the dram to earn more from me.  Might be best in cocktails well married rather than a sipping whiskey.  I'll give it 85% for what it is.

On the nose, stewed fruits (like applesauce being cooked), chewing gum, and a surprising alcohol burn. On the palate, this is hotter than I expected. Juicy Fruit and Big Red chewing gum, some woody bitterness and typical Rye spice that linger for an extra few breaths. Mouthfeel is a bit thin. 4/28/17
While it's a good rye, it pales  in comparison to CR Hand Selected Barrel.

Visual:  In the glass it is a deep amber/gold color. Medium, lasting legs after a swirl.

Nose:  From a distance: floral and vanilla. Up close, more vanilla and, surprisingly, Juicy Fruit Gum in spades!  (Note: I wrote my notes before reading the Distiller review, and I found it interesting that Distiller noted Juicy Fruit in the palate notes, whereas I pick it up very distinctly in the nose). This is a good thing if, like me, you like fruit-bomb whiskies.  

Palate: More vanilla, with a touch of leather. The rye spice comes through a bit more on the palate than the nose, and the fruit morphs into more of the dried, trail mix variety. On the spice side, I detect some difficult to pinpoint baking spices and perhaps a soupçon of mint. 

Finish:  The finish is fairly long and drying, with some tannin bitterness and some heat from the 45% ABV.
Empty glass:  Pecan pralines.

This is one I think I could drink and drink. Do I think it is the best whiskey in the world, and worthy of Mr. Murray’s accolades? Probably not. Also, I’ve read some opinions on-line (after preparing my notes) suggesting that there is some notable batch variation, so it is possible that my bottle differs from what the bible author tasted. I can assert, though, that this is a stellar dram for the price, with its only real flaw being a slightly hot finish.  At $33 USD in my neck of the woods, it is a 5-star value, especially if you’re a fan of north American whiskies.

This is an easy sipping Rye. There is some of the classic pepper, but Crown manages to smooth it out and create a mellow dram. I find the nose light, a bit boozy, and slightly sweet. Maybe pears. The palate is slow to evolve, I find vanilla, marishino cherries, light oak. No char or smoke.  The finish is medium, still sweet but a slow burn. After a few I find my mouth has that dry feel I get with Rye, but it's hidden with just one. (3.5 stars)

One of the better crown products. 

Like the price, solid 3.5 for me.

$35.45 in Ontario
Easy and smooth. Medium, bit of spice. Perfect all round
Not as much of a rye punch as I was expecting. Quite sweet taste with the rye coming through in the finish. Pleasant enough for  $35.45 at LCBO.

Couleur ambré clair. Au nez, notes de vernis à ongle, jus de cerise, vanille, prune non mur, un peu de cannelle, miel et vanille. En bouche, vif, arôme de gomme balloune, floral. Évolution du nez vers des arômes d’écorce d’orange.
Was definitely surprised how much I️ enjoyed this. Would make a decent selection to have on hand.
Nice tasting. Very fruity with a touch of vanilla.

It's definitely pretty good but for me personally leaves a bit to be desired. Compared to Redemption Rye (similar mashbill) it's a decent but smoother. The Redemption will punch you in the face with it's spiced/Rye nose. I suspect this mashbill has corn in it where the redemption does not.

While this Rye is by no means bad I personally find it a bit lacking in terms of what I like in my flavor profiles. It takes a bit of the Rye punch off which can be good or bad depending on what you're in the mood for, but beyond the subtle/interesting nose (for a high rye mash) this ain't got much going for it. It's simply too smooth/subtle after the nose to really get much of anything.

Obviously these reviews are subjective. If you can find this whiskey decently priced (
Great stuff for the price, a perfect every day drinker!
It’s a bit more complex than usual for a Rye.  Especially a Crown. Vanilla some spices. Maybe even a bit of mint.

Not your typical rye, but a good one nonetheless. My personal favorites are the Rittenhouse and Beam pre-prohibition, because I do like the punch your mama ryes. However, this sweet and fruit forward rye is quite good.

Sweet fruit and a little rye vanilla spice on the nose, with the sweetness carrying over on the palate. There is more rye spice there than the nose suggests, with warm cinnamon carried by a bit of vanilla. The finish is lingering and warm, very pleasantly so. Overall I tend to keep this one in the collection, and I would say it is a close 3rd for my favorite rye.

Smooth for sure. Complex it is not. If you are trying to get into rye whiskey, this is a good one to try. Of you have a more developed pallette, this won't do for you. It's just nice and easy to drink Sometimes that is enough! The best way to describe it is a.poor man's Sazerac at the same price point!
Very fruity and sweet with hints of vanilla. Smooth finish. An enjoyable and unique rye.

Fruity nose, rye spices, vanilla. Dried fruit on the palate, dark chocolate, burnt coffee. Very clean but lingering finish of cooked fruit. There is a pleasant smoothness here, paired with a spicy afterburn. Evolves beautifully. An excellent rye.
An excellent rye, the best Crown I have ever tasted. Excellent value for a quality product.

This one goes to show how much palates vary.    While some say it's not very complex and sort of entry level, I couldn't disagree more.   Does it remind me of a particular blue gel toothpaste with sparkles in it that I used as a child?  Yes.  But I also get dill, and an oak character that I usually only find in older and more expensive whisky.   Man. there's loads of different flavours in here compared to anything else in the range except Lot 40.   It drinks like something in a higher range.  I tried it back to back with Wiser's dissertation and could barely tell which one I liked more.  I think it's a steal at $35 cad (regardless of price increase), and feel if Jim Murray wouldn't have awarded it, it would have been considered a hidden gem by many Canadian Rye whisky connoisseurs.  I always really enjoy this rye.

Not a big rye whiskey person, but all the awards in 2015-16 led me to it.  Smooth whiskey with a taste of licorice, spice, and a light wood taste with a fruity spicy aroma. Makes an amazing old fashioned.
At clearance price of $17.00 this was a great buy- would buy again at under $30.00
A little rough but expected from the $20 price point. Still good tho, but again, for the price point

The boy is out; the wife is out. Me by my lonesome.  I had this 375 sized bottle I got some time back. Now is a good time as ever to have a hump day dram. 

Grilled apricots seasoned with dill arrives on the nose. The dill eventually turns more to spearmint.  Some honey notes and cloves and a touch of vanilla and yeasty, sourdough bread.

It arrives spicy and zesty. Once past the spicy sensation, the flavors pull forward.  Cinnamon, birch beer (the other root beer), butterscotch, leather.  The body is medium in density and yet, though the tongue senses the spice, it the texture is quite soft. 

The finish is the stronger part of the dram. Oak spice, spearmint, toffee with trace amounts of apples. Warming and drying that lasts for a good length of time. 

My goto rye for Old Fashioneds and Manhattans is Rittenhouse.  A great sipping rye, with some water is High West Midwinter’s.  This is pretty darn good as a sipper, though not as flavorful and full  as MWND.  Would I have this on my stock?  Probably not.  Though I wouldn’t think twice if the mood strikes for a spicy sipping rye.  [85/100][Tasted: 7/11/18]
Pretty solid for the price in my opinion. Nice flavor with a lot kick. Nothing too complex, but what did you expect?

Warm spice
Slightly sweet
Reminds of Fall/Winter holidays
Very clean smell and taste but body is too young. Just average.
Bland! So bland,was it really a rye? What is with all the accolades?
A stunning rye, as we call it in Canada. I have two bottles from its award-winning year, one to drink and one to save. Caramel and burnt marshmallow. Toffee. Delicious. Top shelf.
Too much ticking in the mouth at the end of taste

Not on Pikesville, Thomas Handy, High West Midnight Winter Dram, or Lock Stock and Barrel 16 level as Jim Murray thinks but is still exquisite. Not your typical Crown Royal. Combines smoothness with sweet and spicy flavors from pepper, vanilla, cinnamon, pepper, barrel spices, fruit, chocolate, and caramel.

Pleasantly sweet fruit on the nose. Starts out promising on the palette with a solid base of fruit,wood and spice, but ultimately comes up lacking in overall flavor. The base continues through the medium finish, but ultimately disappointing. Does not hold up well in a Manhattan.
Grain, sweet, medicinal, fruit, slight spice notes.
spicy and surprisingly fruity, particularly cherry
Sweet. Smooth. Most enjoyable for the price. A good, solid effort.

Huh... definitely sweet and fruity.  Reminded me of Double Bubble gum a bit, mostly on the nose.  The Rye flavour comes out, which I seem to usually like.  A hint of scallywag.  Yeah, I like this one.
See multi-review on Whistlepig Vermont Estate Oak 15yo.
I think I like j.b. rye more
pas pour rien qu'il a déjà été nommé le meilleur whisky au monde il y a quelques années. tout simplement un excellent rye whisky! meilleur à mes yeux que le Canadian Club 100% rye
Tasted in a home from a plastic mini shot glass. Shot repeatedly. Burned but not too badly. Toasty notes.

Nose: vanilla, butterscotch, cinnamon.
Palate: a little spice, orange peel. Finish is medium length and spicy.
A little water added boldness to the nose, and a nice spice to the palate.
Overall: very tasty, and a good value.
My second favorite rye behind High West Double Rye. Nice blend of flavors, smooth and easy to drink. Great value.
Apple, mild sugar, fresh, full.  Sharp and sweet.  Very accessible.
Profoundly fruity and spicy. Also a bit of a burn at the end but still enjoyable. Especially good for the $18 sale I got on it!

Nose: Fruity, Rye, Pear, 

Taste: Orange, Cinnamon, Artificial Sweetness, Spicy
Not really a rye some honey sans wax with a very smooth finish and no bite. I would say a good bottle for someone getting into rye.

This won whisky of the year for a reason back in 2016 and for the price is an excellent bottle to regularly have in your collection.

On the nose: Sweetness, Perfect amount of Rye, and subtle barrel. Overall classy depth.

On the pallet: Sip a bit and let this roll over and under the back of your tongue (at room temperature) several times while inhaling a bit of breath in between. Rich and full sweetness tempered by Rye and oak mix together create a blissful experience that continues to get better as your glass gets lower over the course of the entire experience.

This is best enjoyed neat at room temperature.
Mixes really well, on the sweeter side for a Rye
Not getting much if any of the fruity aromas others claim this whiskey has. The black pepper, caramel and vanilla notes are much more present
Sweet rye nose and palate, spicy finish
Very good rye for the price. Nice fruity finish, easy to drink
To me CR Rye is a mixture of fruity and sweet with just enough bite to keep you honest.

I am grateful to Jim Murray for challenging me to try Northern Harvest by calling it the Best Whisky in the World. It started me on an odyssey through Canadian drams that continues to make me very happy. After four bottles of NH, I can say that one was sublime, two were great, and one was so-so. 

At its best, NH is somehow delicate, crunchy, aromatic and spicy all at once. This bottle has a lovely sweet banoffee aroma with a palate to match - the biscuity base comes through especially nicely. Sipping on it’s light, not syrupy, but still toasty and delicious with a long finish of baking spices. 

The best bottle of NH I’ve finished really was among the best on a shelf of 50-odd from Scotland, Canada, Japan and the USA. And it is unquestionably FABULOUS value.
Drinkable but lacks the spice and complexity of other ryes.
Not a true rye mash, was ok
Not horrible, but not great. There’s cinnamon on the nose, and I think that’s what turns me off from this rye
one drop to remove the booze nose

Nose: Delicate but loaded with ripe fruit: apple & pear (calvados), allspice & nutmeg, plum, a little sherried dark fruit, juicy fruit gum with a touch of fingernail polish.

Palate: Raspberries, apple, pear, & spice  ala calvados, honeyed vanilla, youthfull grain character and barrel spice. Sour apples and baking spice again on the finish.

This one hits and fades quick but the finish lingers like a sour apple lifesaver.
Spicy, cinnamon on the nose, full taste and grain here.
i can see why some like it & some don't. rye taste is sour, sweetness floats underneath.

Crown Royal Northern Harvest Rye. 90 pts. Surprising apple pie aroma, but the flavour is dominated by oak and a peppery spice, with a light caramel and hints of pumpkin pie.  A very good rye, and not a bad Whisky in general.
Solid, nothing that jumps out at you

I’m a fan of crown and ryes and this one hits both. Fantastic sipper or on the rocks and especially since I found it on sale for $24/bottle! May have to go back and buy more.

After revisiting this one I’m knocking off a star. I get a lot of ethanol but not in a good way. This just doesn’t taste the same as I remember when I first cracked it open. I’ve been forced to add a few ice cubes to get this one down. 9/1/19

Update 12/4/19
Tried this one again as it has been sitting half full/empty for a few months in the cabinet. The ethanol has gone down and is now more "spicy" as a rye should be. Either this one has been changing profiles on me or it's my flavor profile changing. Probably a bit of both. Anyways, I seem to like this one again for what it is. Bumped up a 1/4 star. :-)

I have heard that this product is not consistent bottle to bottle. No idea if true or not. 
This bottle smells like a rye. The nose has that rye spike on top of a base of smooth, sweet, vanilla.
The taste is also rye and an interesting mix of approachable and rye bite. The base is smooth, not a lot going on until the swallow and finish. The finish is where the rye makes itself known with a spike of spice that subsides into a nice tingle on the tongue. The mouth feel is light. After a few sips I found that the rye tingle built and started a little sooner. The rye tingle and spice was still a spike: subtle, then a big spike, to a quick fade, and a nice lingering tingle. I like the lingering tingle more than the flavors. 
Enjoyable. Would not turn down. May purchase again but not an always have on the shelf. 
This in an odd spot for me. When I reach for a rye I generally want a more aggressive flavor experience.
Nice flavor. Similar to regular Crown Royal. Smooth and tasty.

Can’t say I have the most refined palette but this is certainly sweet and almost fruity on the tongue and nose. The Distiller review nails it in referencing Juicy Fruit. It’s a sweet familiar taste spiked with a good amount of spiciness. Easy to sip at on a daily basis
Definitely not the “best whiskey in the world”.  It is, however, a pleasantly spicy rye that could, except that there are just as good at a lower price, become a favorite everyday rye.
A must try. Great adult beverage.  Easy to drink, not too sweet or too spicy, just the right combination.  I'll keep going back for this one.  $30 at my local state store.
Terrible, sweet nose with hints of apple, odd bitter taste and terrible finish

One of my fave Canadian whiskeys! Smell is so complex vanilla citrus wood notes, taste is vanilla and almond and complex best whiskey for dollar for sure! Opens with a little water and lends itself to more rye so tastey :)

Nose: Vanilla, sweet grass
Mouth: Sweet flavour with a touch of spice to balance. Notes of vanilla, rye, and toffee
Finish: Smooth, medium length and consistent, lingering spicy caramel

I’ve tried this five or six times, and it has taken over 4 months in the bottle for me to finally enjoy this. The nose is really fruity, green apple, plum, a touch of citrus, and floral. The taste is vanilla with a bit of citrus and green apple. The mouth feel is creamy. Finish is a bit off, kind of like nail polish remover. The finish really hurts this whiskey.

First Rye whisky I taste.. Very spicy, long and strong after taste. Little Vainilla and some burn. A good whisky to taste, nothing extraordinary

Follow me on insta: @whiskperience
This is all vanilla and spicy in the nose and taste. Little burn. Good flavour close to bourbon.
Pops of vanilla in the nose with notes of cut grass. Super soft on the palate with mild spice and woody notes. Fades into a quick finish.
This has got to be one of my favorite whiskeys. Crown Royal has a bad rep, but this is good.  It is smooth and a little sweeter than regular Crown Royal.
Light on the nose with hint of sweetness and oak. Light and sweet on the palate like cotton candy with a kick of lingering rye spice.
I usually go for Scotch, but sometimes I’m in the mood for rye.  This is my favorite rye.   It has a great spice and vanilla flavor.

Fruity sweet and spice on the nose.
Medium body, creamy in the mouth, sweetest whisky I tried so far.
Finish medium long herbal like licorice
The best of Crown Royal’s stock in my mind. No need to mix as a cocktail it is good enough to be enjoyed by itself.

Very strong floral and vanilla tones on the nose with a subtle hint of dried apricots. Slightly oily texture on the palate with an explosion of Creme Brulee and orange peel-Marmalade. A slight hint of spearmint at the end. A pleasantly surprising drawn out finish escalating the creamy vanilla, sweet custard with a dash of spicy cinnamon to finish. An amazing dram. One of my all time favourites.

Nose: Baking spices, cereal, light wood spices.

Palate: Gentle oak note, rich butterscotch, spiced vanilla. Develops into soft peppery notes.

Finish: Smooth & creamy.

If there's a hidden gem in your local store it may well be dressed in a white gunny sack looking bag bearing a tiny crown logo.   Because it's Crown or because it's Rye or because it's Crown Rye, this one get's overlooked far more often than not, and that's probably a bigger shame than just about anything being passed over in liquor stores these days.  That especially holds true since the Rye offering from CR is often one of the better deals going. 

So why is Crown Rye really all that?  First it's just a great rye taste with a nice sweet bouquet that forebodes the juicy flavors contained there in.  Juicy Fruit gum? Well maybe,  it is a sweet taster for a rye and that alone is worthy of some interest.  While not everyone may enjoy their rye with such attributes, Crowns offering not only brings the sweet flavors but as I always say, it's also as much about what isn't present in your liquor.  There is nothing young, green or otherwise inferior about Northern Harvest, it starts smooth yet spicy, remains juicy sweet through the middle and ends just as pleasantly. 

Northern Harvest Rye was reputedly over produced up front and wound up being found at discount prices, that glut is probably well passed in many areas but just the same the "good deal" awaiting may not be the one you wanted but is still waiting patiently, just the same.   If you like rye and haven't tried it yet, do yourself a solid and slosh down some Northern Harvest.    Highly drinkable and easy on the wallet.   We call that a win win.
This is my favorite rye.  Most ryes are a little heavy on the spice and licorice, but this is really balanced.
Nice rye flavour. Not overly smooth. Some maple and oak notes. Great for cocktails and I always have a bottle in my bar for this purpose but wouldn't drink straight.

I can't see myself drinking this straight, but it does have a bit of depth. The whiskey is harsh and its flavor is predominantly the sour bitterness of rye with hints of wood, occasional pops of sweet fruit, and an unfortunately oppressive layer of clove that makes up bulk of the finish. For its price, this is a very good whiskey and is a great choice for mixing.
I mean, it’s a Crown Royal Rye. What can one expect? Still, with that being said, it exceeded expectations. Spicy and quite deep for a Crown product.
Nice, very smooth, good rye flavours, only downside is short finish.
Smell of spirit is strong at first. Needs time to breathe. Oaky sweet taste. Not bad for its price.
Nice balance of fruit, grain, spice, and heat.  For the price, this is the best Crown product available.
Light Menthol smell mixed with caramel. Soft in mouth, easy to go. Back draft of pleasure and spicy wet wood in the end.

Nose: Fruity Bubble Gum (Fruits like sour red apple, pear, banana, strawberries, raspberries, mixed with some peppermint), spearmint, a hint of oak, some vanilla, a touch of light/aged caramel, some baking spices (sweet and tangy ginger, sweet cinnamon, cloves), gingerbread cookies covered in apricot marmalade, rye spice and mixed pepper (white and black pepper), some sweet tea, a hint of lemon and a touch of maple, finely aged oak sweetness, some chocolate orange, rye bread, faintest hint of butterscotch candies, herbal notes (some anice and a hint of dill), some cherry marmalade, sweet green paprika, lemon peel

Palate: Sweet spearmint, oakiness and rye spice, botanicals and spices(cloves, ginger, juniper berries), some slightly bittersweet orange/orange peel, dried fruits ( raisins, dates, dried apricots), sweet and slightly tangy apricots, green paprika, oak spice, a bit of ripe pear, some hops and hop bitterness, bitter peppermint, a hint of peach a bit of dark mint chocolate/dark chocolate orange, some oaky caramel and vanilla, sweet tea, grainy rye bread and sourdough bread, peppermint tea and green tea

Finish: Lemon peel and peppermint, rye grains and rye spice, sweet tea, some fruity bubblegum, rye bitterness, faint hints of deep and rich caramel, a hint of cinnamon, a reminder of oak, more green tea notes

My first recorded taste, but I've had a lot of this.  It's something of a guilty pleasure, in fact.  I drink this on ice 80% of the time.  CRNHR is a totally casual drink for me when I'm just hanging around the house and want something tasty that I don't have to pay any attention to.  This is it!

This is candy - butterscotch, vanilla and a blush of pepper to let you know its a grown-up candy. If you try it neat you'll get a smidge of dill, a bit of allspice.  On ice or off, the barrel's influence is there.  This is a solid Canadian rye, not as colorfully full flavored as Lot 40 but it doesn't need to apologize for offering up its own take on being a polite, flavorful dram. This is a solid offering, a bit ahead of the pack in fact.  

Not long ago I ran into a 50% off sale on this.  I wish I'd bougth a dozen bottles, but as it was I think I absconded with 3. At the going price of $30 or so for a 750 this isn't a steal but it is a solid value. I think bottles of this will find a way in and out of my cabinet for years to come.
Not my favorite. Regular crown is way better

Juicy Fruit gum on the nose with a bit of spice.. more fruit on the palate and smooth. Fruit continues through the finish with a little warm vanilla and the slightest hint of mint. I expected it to be sweet and fruity after reading all the reviews but was also expecting more spice from a 90 rye mash. Not missing the extra spice tho, this is a great neat pour.
